argumentText:
For $p=1$ the result follows immediately from the triangle inequality,
so we may assume $p>1$.

We have
$$|a_k+b_k|^p=|a_k+b_k| |a_k+b_k|^{p-1} \leq (|a_k|+|b_k|)|a_k+b_k|^{p-1}$$
by the triangle inequality. Therefore we have
$$|a_k+b_k|^p  \leq |a_k||a_k+b_k|^{p-1} + |b_k||a_k+b_k|^{p-1}$$ Set
$q=\frac{p}{p-1}$. Then $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=1$, so by the Hölder
inequality we have $$\sum_{k=0}^n |a_k||a_k+b_k|^{p-1} \leq
    \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k|^p \right)^{\frac{1}{p}} 
    \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k+b_k|^{(p-1)q} \right)^{\frac{1}{q}}$$
$$\sum_{k=0}^n |b_k||a_k+b_k|^{p-1} \leq
    \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |b_k|^p \right)^{\frac{1}{p}} 
    \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k+b_k|^{(p-1)q} \right)^{\frac{1}{q}}$$
Adding these two inequalities, dividing by the factor common to the
right sides of both, and observing that $(p-1)q=p$ by definition, we
have $$\left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k+b_k|^p \right)^{1-\frac{1}{q}}
   \leq \frac{ \sum_{k=0}^n (|a_k|+|b_k|)|a_k+b_k|^{p-1} }{ \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k+b_k|^{p} \right)^{\frac{1}{q}} }
   \leq \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |a_k|^p \right)^{\frac{1}{p}} +
        \left( \sum_{k=0}^n |b_k|^p \right)^{\frac{1}{p}}$$ Finally,
observe that $1-\frac{1}{q}=\frac{1}{p}$, and the result follows as
required. The proof for the integral version is analogous.
